Mesoporous 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts were successfully prepared by doping Ce and calcining Mn-BTC (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) for ozone catalytic decomposition. The 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity under the relative humidity (RH) range from less than 5–65 %, giving 100 % conversion of 40 ppm O3 after 6 h. Series of physicochemical characterizations including XRD, TG, SEM, HR-TEM, ICP-OES, BET, XPS and H2-TPR were introduced the relationship of calcination temperature, catalysts structure and ozone catalytic performance. The results demonstrated that the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst had the highest Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olatt ratios and the largest specific surface compared with those of other samples, which are crucial to decompose ozone. In addition, better dispersion of crystals, larger pore volume, more oxygen vacancies, and better low-temperature reducibility are also conducive to ozone decomposition. This research establishes the basis for the application of manganese-based MOFs for ozone decomposition. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Ozone Calcination Catalytic Decomposition Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The concentration of ground-level ozone has increased as a result of the swift development of global industry and the economy, resulting in serious photochemical smog pollution [1,2]. In addition, indoor disinfection and the operation of high-voltage discharge equipment will cause indoor ozone to exceed the standard [3–5], making serious damage to the human respiratory tract and lungs, and increasing the risk of cardiovascular disease [6]. Therefore, eliminating ground-level ozone is necessary to safeguard both the ecological environment and public health. Ozone elimination methods mainly include thermal decomposition [7], physical adsorption [8], chemical adsorption [9] and catalytic decomposition [10–13]. Catalytic decomposition has merits of simplified operation and no secondary pollutants, which is believed to be the most potential and environmentally friendly ozone treatment method. Nevertheless, the expensive price of noble metal catalysts (Au [14], Ag [15], Pt [16]) and the undesirable catalytic performance of some transition metal catalysts (Fe [17], Ni [18], Co [19]) restricted the application of these methods. Because of their excellent tunable structure and environmental compatibility, manganese oxides (MnOx) are prime candidates for ozone decomposition [20–22]. Recent studies revealed the catalytic activity of MnOx catalysts was positively correlated with the oxygen vacancies density [22,23]. Unfortunately, manganese oxides catalysts lack sufficient oxygen vacancies, the accumulation of other species and the competitive adsorption of water molecules will lead to greatly reduced the ozone conversion rate in high humidity conditions [24,25]. The Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6 doped MnOx catalyst was reported that owed the large surface area, richer oxygen vacancies and superior moisture resistance, but the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst decreased at relative humidity (RH) = 65 % [26]. Therefore, designing materials that can efficiently and stably remove ozone over a wider range of humidity remains a considerable challenge. Over the past two decades, Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted a host of academic attention, which were widely applied in multiple territories such as gas adsorption [27], gas storage [27,28], heterogeneous catalysis [29], and sensing [30]. MOFs with abundant porous structure, large specific surface area, coordination unsaturated metal sites, and structural diversity have showed unique advantages in various catalytic reactions [31–33]. Recently, MOFs were applied to decompose ozone. A Mn-based metal organic framework, [Mn3(μ3-OH)2(TTPE) (H2O)4]·2 H2O, synthesized by Mn(NO3)2·6H2O and 1,1,2,2-tetrakis(4-(2H-tetrazol-5-yl)phenyl)ethane was reported that can efficiently eliminate ozone over the entire humidity range [34]. However, its expensive price and difficult to obtain organic ligands limit the application of this catalyst in real life. Furthermore, the structure of MOFs is unstable, the ozone conversion will reduce for long time reaction, and is not conducive to reuse [35]. Research has found materials derived from MOFs by calcining could enhance their stability, while maintaining the morphological characteristics of MOFs [36,37]. Therefore, MOFs are also used as sacrificial templates to prepare porous materials with regulatable pore size, highly dispersed active components, and special structures. The catalyst prepared by modified MOFs could contain both porous carbon structure and metal oxides nanoparticles, which have exhibited satisfactory performance in heterogeneous catalysis. For example, Cu-Co/C catalyst prepared by Cu-MOFs showed high activity for toluene decomposition, it was confirmed the catalyst had a unique porous structure, the higher specific surface area and better stability after calcining [38]. Heretofore, the ozone decomposition has seldom been studied by applying MOFs and their derived materials, the development of ozone decomposition technologies and the expansion of the use of MOFs materials are both greatly impacted by this field of study. From the literature research given above, we prepared the new porous 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts for ozone decomposition in this study. With regard to we know, there are no reports on the CeOx/MnOx catalysts by calcination of Ce-doped Mn-BTC for the removal of ozone under humid conditions. The as-synthesized catalyst of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst achieved 100% ozone conversion at room temperature for 6 h when the RH ranged from less than 5–65%, which was suitable for ozone removal under low gas flow rate applications such as home and office appliances. Furthermore, varieties of physicochemical characterizations have been applied to research the relationship of calcination temperature, structures of catalysts and the performance of ozone decomposition. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Materials N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %), cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.5 %), benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 98 %), manganese acetate (CH3COO)2Mn, 98 %), ethanol (C2H5OH, 99 %) were purchased from Sigma-Aladdin and were of analytical grade purity. The deionized water obtained by ultrapure water mechanism (NPTK-4G). 2.2 Preparation of Mn-BTC The Mn-BTC was synthesized through a hydrothermal procedure. 3.89 g (CH3COO)2Mn was dissolved in 40 ml deionized water, 2.36 g H3BTC was dissolved in 40 ml DMF, the solutions were mixed and stirred for 10 min. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred into a 120 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 150 °C for 48 h. The colorless crystals were washed alternately with deionized water and ethanol, and the washed suspension solution was separated by centrifuge. Lastly, the white solid Mn-BTC was gained after drying at 150 °C for 12 h. 2.3 Preparation of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y 2 g Mn-BTC and 0.22 g Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O were dissolved in 50 ml deionized water under ultrasound for 30 min. Afterwards, the suspension was transformed into a 120 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 150 °C for 12 h. After it cooled to room temperature, the mixed solid sample was separated by centrifuge, the 10Ce/Mn-BTC was obtained by drying at 150 °C for 12 h. The 10Ce/Mn-BTC was put into a muffle furnace, and calcined at different temperatures (300 °C, 350 °C, 400 °C, 450 °C) for 6 h, subsequently obtained a black solid 10CeOx/MnOx-Y after natural cooling to room temperature, where Y represents the calcination temperature. According to ICP-OES analysis, the catalysts' real Ce contents were close to the theoretical value in Table 1. Fig. 1. 2.4 Characterization methods XRD analysis was conducted on an X-ray diffractometer (PW3040/60X, PANalytical, Netherlands) with Cu-Kα radiation. TG analysis was tested on the synchronous thermal analysis instrument (STA449F3, Netzsch, Germany) at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min on air. SEM analysis was conducted on an electron microscopy (Apreo 2Cx, Thermo Scientific, USA). The real content of Ce in the catalyst was tested by ICP-OES (5110, Agilent, USA), the sample was dissolved by nitric acid before detecting. HR-TEM analysis was performed on transmission electron microscope (FEI Talos F200X, FEI, USA). BET analysis was characterized by the automated gas sorption instrument (ASAP2020M, Mack, USA), the sample was ventilated at 120 °C for 6 h before the test. XPS analysis was performed on X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (K-Alpha, Thermo Scientific, USA) to study the chemical states of surface elements (Mn 2p, Ce 3d, O 1s, Mn 3s), in which the binding energy was calibrated by the C1s spectrum (284.6 eV). H2-TPR test was performed on temperature programmed chemisorption analyzer (DAS-7000, Huasi, China). 100 mg of samples were placed in the reactor and processed for 20 min at 200 °C with He (30 ml/min). After cooling to 50 °C, the reactor ascended at a rate of 10 °C/ min to 700 °C, and the 5 vol% H2/Ar gas mixture was supplied into the reactor at a rate of 30 ml/min simultaneously. The H2 consumption amount of the sample was calibrated with CuO. 2.5 O3 decomposition test The catalytic performance of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts for O3 decomposition was dynamically conducted in a fixed-bed continuous reactor with an inner diameter of 4 mm, and O3 was generated by the UV lamp ozone generator, the initial O3 concentration was maintained at 40 ppm. 100 mg of as-prepared catalysts (40–60 meshes) were loaded into the quartz reactor and the total gas flow rate was maintained at 1000 ml/min. The O3 detector (MOT500-LT-O3) was applied to monitor O3 inlet and outlet concentration, the constant water bath foamer was applied to regulate the relative humidity (RH), and the RH and temperature were monitored by a temperature and humidity controller (GSP-8A) in the system. The O3 conversion of all ozone catalysts was calculated via the following formula: R O 3 = C 1 − C 2 C 1 × 100 % where C 1 and C 2 represent the inlet and outlet concentrations of O3, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Mn-BTC template Fig. 2a shows the diffraction peaks of as-synthesized Mn-BTC, which was consistent with the Mn-BTC reported in the previous literature[39] as shown in Fig. 2a, proved the Mn-BTC pure crystalline material was successfully synthesized. Fig. 2b shows SEM image of as-synthesized Mn-BTC. It could be observed that the Mn-BTC displayed an accumulation of rod-like particles with a smooth surface. The diameter of Mn-BTC was concentrated within the scope of 60–140 nm, and its mean diameter and mean length were calculated to be approximately 100 nm and 700 nm, respectively. TG was performed to analyze the thermostability of as-synthesized Mn-BTC, and the result was shown in Fig. 2c. The total weight of sample had undergone three stages of changes: the total sample weight lost 13.11% under the temperature range of 30–160 °C, which could be attributed to evaporation of the coordinated water and the adsorbed water; the sample quality showed a stable state at 170–350 °C, indicating that the crystal structure was not much change, and the original three-dimensional structure of MOFs was basically maintained; when the temperature further raised from 405 °C to 440 °C, the total sample weight lost 50.64 %, indicating that the organic framework gradually decomposed and the three-dimensional structure collapsed in the temperature range. In order to fully oxidize the metal on the MOFs framework while retaining the three-dimensional structure of the MOFs framework, 300 °C, 350 °C, 400 °C, and 450 °C were selected as the calcination temperatures of the catalysts. 3.2 Morphology and phase structures of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y Fig. 3 shows the diffraction peaks of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts. From Fig. 3, the samples no longer retained the crystalline phases of Mn-BTC after calcination. The 10CeOx/MnOx-300, 10CeOx/MnOx-350 and 10CeOx/MnOx-400 catalysts had similar typical diffraction peaks at 2θ = 23.13°, 32.95°, 38.23°, 55.18°, which were assigned to the Mn2O3 [PDF#41–1442]. The diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 crystals gradually strengthened and the peak width became narrower as the calcination temperature increased, indicating the increased calcination temperature promoted metal clusters oxidation in the MOFs framework, and the resulting samples had higher crystallinity. The diffraction peaks of 10CeOx/MnOx-450 catalyst at 2θ = 18.00°, 28.88°, 32.31°, 36.08° were related to the Mn3O4 [PDF#24–0734], indicating the oxidation state of manganese changed from Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 at 450 °C. However, the research has reported that the ozone decomposition effect of Mn2O3 was superior to Mn3O4 [40]. It is worth noting that no obvious pure cerium oxide (CeOx) phase was observed, indicating that cerium oxide was amorphous on catalyst surface [41]. SEM was carried to further characterized the morphologies of as-prepared catalysts, the influence of calcination temperature on the 10CeOx/MnOx-Y shapes was shown in Fig. 4a-d. It could be seen the surface of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts became rougher and formed void, attributed to the decomposition of organic components into COx, NOx and water vapor during calcination. In addition, the structure of MOFs collapsed from the inside, the size of rod-like structures gradually reduced, the crystals gradually changed to nanoparticle morphology and agglomerated. Fig. 4e-h shows the TEM image of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts. From the TEM image, the rod-like 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts were composed of a plurality of nanocrystals, in which the size of the nanocrystals was mainly concentrated between 10 and 42 nm. However, the larger size crystals in the 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts were due to the crystal agglomeration caused by higher calcination temperature. Interestingly, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst still retained the rod-like structure of Mn-BTC, partially showing short stick fragments, and had better dispersion. Thus, the appropriate calcination temperature could reduce the occurrence of crystal particle agglomeration and conduced to enlarge their specific surface area. Depending on the catalyst performance, the catalytic activity might well be enhanced with the larger specific surface area because the catalyst could have richer accessible active sites[42]. In addition, the crystal plane spacing measured and calculated by Digital Micrograph was shown in the HR-TEM image. The 10CeOx/MnOx-300, 10CeOx/MnOx-350 and 10CeOx/MnOx-400 catalysts had an obvious inter-planar distance of Mn2O3: 0.25, 0.28 and 0.37 nm corresponded to the (311), (222) and (211) crystal planes of Mn2O3. The inter-planar distance of 0.21, 0.24 and 0.47 nm of 10CeOx/MnOx-450 catalyst corresponded to the (220), (211) and (101) crystal planes of Mn3O4, indicating the oxidation state of manganese changed from Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 at 450 °C, consistent with the XRD analysis. 3.3 BET characterization of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y Fig. 5 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts. From Fig. 5a, the whole as-prepared catalysts exhibited the type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with an H3 type hysteresis loop over high P/P0 between 0.75 and 0.98, demonstrating the 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts were mesoporous materials [43,44]. From Fig. 5b, the catalysts pore size was mainly distributed 2–6 nm, and contained a small amount of micropores, which further indicated the 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts had mesoporous structure. Table 1 summarized the specific surface areas, pore volume and pore size of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts. Compared with the Mn-BTC, the surface area of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts were significantly increased after calcination. However, the specific surface areas and the quantity of mesopores of the catalysts gradually decreased as increasing of calcination temperature, the reason can be attributed to the phenomenon of sintering and agglomeration of crystal particles. In addition, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst owned the highest surface area of 64.438 m2/g, it could further expose active sites in the catalyst, was beneficial to the contact adsorption between ozone molecules and active sites, promoting ozone decomposition. Hence, appropriate calcination temperature helped to enlarge the surface area of catalysts, and avoided agglomeration of crystal particles. 3.4 XPS characterization of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y Fig. 6 shows the XPS patterns of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts. Table 2 summarized the surface chemical compositions molar ratios and chemical states. Fig. 6a shows the XPS spectrum of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts Mn 2p3/2, the peaks at 641.0 eV and 643.3 eV were respectively attributed to Mn3+ and Mn4+ [45,46]. The ratios of Mn3+/Mn4+ were greater than 1 as seen in Table 2, indicating that manganese mostly presented in the form of Mn3+ in the catalysts, consistent with the XRD results. Moreover, it could be observed that the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ showed a trend of fall first then rise with increasing of calcination temperature, and the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst showed the maximum Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio of 4.07. As previously reported, Mn3+ was beneficial to generate free electrons that were then transported from manganese sites to ozone [47]. In addition, abundant Mn3+ meant more oxygen vacancies were produced via the following equation [48] so as to keep electrostatic equilibrium: 4 Mn 4 + + O 2 − → 4 Mn 4 + + 1 / 2 O 2 + 2 e − + ∎ → 2 Mn 4 + + 2 Mn 3 + + 1 / 2 O 2 + ∎ where ∎ represented oxygen vacancies. Important responsibilities as active sites are played by the oxygen vacancies in ozone decomposition, which can promote ozone removal. Hence, appropriate calcination temperature was conducive to increase the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ and improved ozone decomposition. Fig. 6b shows the XPS spectrum of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y Mn 3 s. The average valence state of Mn was computed via the following equation[49]: AOS = 8.956–1.126ΔEs, where ΔEs represented the energy differences between two peaks of the Mn 3s spectrum, AOS calculations were shown in Table 2. It could be observed the average valence state of Mn in all catalysts was less than 3, indicating the presence of lower manganese oxidation states and more unsaturated manganese atoms in the catalyst, which improved the mobility of O atoms in the crystal structure and created more oxygen vacancies, conducing to ozone removal [50]. Fig. 6c shows the XPS spectrum of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y Ce 3d, the peak at 881.7 (U), 884.8 (U'), 888.2 (U'') and 897.8 (U′'') eV were ascribed to Ce 3d5/2, the peak at 900.6 (V), 903.6 (V'), 906.9 (V'') and 916.12 (V′'') eV were ascribed to Ce 3d3/2, which could be divided into two portions in accordance with the peak fitting. The peak at 884.8 and 903.6 eV were ascribed to Ce3+, the others were ascribed to Ce4+ [51,52]. From Table 2, the molar ratios of Ce3+/Ce4+ exhibited a decreasing trend with increasing calcination temperature, indicating cerium was oxidized more fully at the higher calcination temperature. The 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst had the maximum Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio of 0.37, the abundant Ce3+ contributed to electron transport between Mn and Ce via this route: Mn3+ + Ce4+ ⇌ Mn4+ + Ce3+, and enhanced the ability of activated oxygen species [53]. Hence, appropriate calcination temperature was conducive to increase the ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+, facilitated electron transport and ozone decomposition. Fig. 6d shows the XPS spectrum of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y O 1 s. The asymmetrical peak could be divided into two parts, the peak at 529.5–530.1 eV and the peak at 531–531.7 eV were respectively attributed to lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen [13]. From Table 2, it could be observed that the Oads/Olatt ratios over 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts reduced in the following sequence: 10CeOx/MnOx-300 (1.01) > 10CeOx/MnOx-400 (1.00) > 10CeOx/MnOx-350 (0.53) > 10CeOx/MnOx-450 (0.49), the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst exhibited the highest Oads/Olatt ratio, indicating the catalyst had more abundant surface adsorbed oxygen species (O2-, O2 2-). According to literature reported, water molecules and oxygen molecules readily combined with oxygen vacancies in metal oxide catalysts to generate surface adsorbed oxygen species, which inclined to take part in the oxidation reaction [54]. Furthermore, the rich Oads indicated the catalyst existed oxygen vacancies. Hence, appropriate calcination temperature was conducive to form abundant surface adsorbed oxygen species, and promoted ozone decomposition. 3.5 H2-TPR characterization of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y Fig. 7 shows the H2-TPR spectrum of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts. From Fig. 7, all samples showed two reduction peaks, the low temperature peak was ascribed to Mn2O3 reduction to Mn3O4, whereas the high temperature peak was ascribed to Mn3O4 reduction to MnO [55,56]. It could be detected that the reduction peak of 10CeOx/MnOx-350, 10CeOx/MnOx-400, and 10CeOx/MnOx-450 shifted towards the high-temperature peak, indicating increased calcination temperature decreased the reducibility of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts, which should be attributed to the conversion of manganese oxides to a low valence state after high temperature calcination, the reducibility of manganese oxides was decreased. Furthermore, the total H2 consumption of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts were summarized in Table 3. For comparison, the H2 consumption of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst was higher than other samples, and it had the lower temperature of reduction peak, indicating the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst had better reducibility, which could exhibit superior reactivity for ozone decomposition [53]. However, the low-temperature reduction peak area of 10CeOx/MnOx-450 catalyst was dramatically minished, attributed to Mn3O4 crystal phase of 10CeOx/MnOx-450, consistent with the XRD results. Therefore, appropriate calcination temperature helped to improve the reducibility of the catalyst. 3.6 Ozone decomposition performance and structure-activity relationship Taking practical condition into account, 40 ppm O3, RH = 65 % and the total gas flow rate of 1000 ml/min were set to test the ozone conversion at room temperature. Fig. 8a shows the ozone decomposition performance of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts. From Fig. 8a, the ozone conversion kept at 100% after 6 h for 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst, the 10CeOx/MnOx-350 catalyst exhibited 92 % conversion for ozone after 6 h, the conversion of ozone was dramatically decreased after 1 h for the 10CeOx/MnOx-400 and 10CeOx/MnOx-450 catalysts, kept at 60 % and 58 % after 6 h respectively, the Mn-BTC had almost no catalytic activity for ozone decomposition. For comparison, the ozone decomposition performance of commercial MnO2 catalyst was investigated and the ozone conversion was only 20 % after 6 h, it was attributed to MnO2 lack sufficient active sites, competitive adsorption of moisture and accumulation of O2 2- lead to low ozone conversion. Fig. 8b shows the ozone decomposition performance of catalysts without doping Ce after calcination modification. It could be clearly observed that their ozone conversion rates were significantly reduced within 6 h, which were lower than that of 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts under the same test conditions, indicating Ce doping helped to improve the catalytic activity for ozone decomposition. In contrast, the ozone conversion of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst was higher than other samples and the commercial MnO2 catalyst, indicating the ozone decomposition efficiency of the catalyst decreased with increasing calcination temperature. In addition, the effect of total gas flow rate on the ozone conversion of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst was shown in Fig. 8c. From Fig. 8c, the ozone conversion of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst decreased with the total gas flow rate increased, its ozone conversion kept at 49 % for 6 h at the total gas flow rate of 1800 ml/min, RH = 65 % and 40 ppm O3. It indicated that the ozone conversion of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst would reduce at the higher gas flow rate, attributed to the decrease of ozone residence time and the increase of ozone treatment capacity. Fig. 8d shows that 100% ozone conversion of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst at ≤ 5 %, 25 %, 45 %, 65 % RH and 40 ppm O3, meanwhile, when the RH was switched between ≤ 5 % and 65 %, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst could respond fast within 5 min and maintained 100% ozone removal rate, showing the exceptional adaptability to the environment. From the XRD, HR-TEM and BET results, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300, 10CeOx/MnOx-350 and 10CeOx/MnOx-400 catalysts were composed of Mn2O3 phase, the 10CeOx/MnOx-450 catalyst was composed of Mn3O4 phase, and diffraction peaks of the Mn-BTC were not observed. The specific surface area and the quantity of mesoporous of the catalysts decreased as increasing calcination temperature, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst had the highest specific surface area, which was beneficial to adsorb ozone and expose more reactive sites, enhanced the ozone conversion efficiency of the catalyst in high humid condition. The higher temperature calcination will cause the collapse of the framework of MOFs, and the crystal particles will agglomerate, causing the reduction of the surface area. Through H2-TPR analysis, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst could consume more hydrogen and had the lower reduction peak temperature, therefore it had excellent reducibility and improved ozone decomposition activity. XPS confirmed that the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst existed more abundant Mn3+, Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen, which were helpful for electron transport, in addition, they were beneficial to form more oxygen vacancies and oxidative active species on catalyst surface, enhancing the ability of active oxygen and improving ozone decomposition. Therefore, the sample of appropriate calcination temperature exhibited better activity owing to its more amount of oxygen vacancies and reducibility. The comparison of different ozone catalysts reported previously was summarized in Table 4. Jia et al. synthesized the MnCO3 catalyst by a co-precipitation method, which could maintain the ozone conversion of 85% under14 ppm O3 and dry conditions after 22 h. Wei et al. synthesized the CeMn/ZSM-81 catalyst by modifying ZSM zeolite, which was tested under the conditions of high ozone concentration of 600 pm and the total gas flow of 600 ml/min, achieved the ozone conversion of 93 % for 6 h. Interestingly, MIL-100 prepared by Wang et al. could achieve 100 % ozone conversion when the RH ≥ 45 %, attributed to the ozone decomposition via a series of free-radicals formed by reactions between FeII, FeIII and water molecules under humid conditions. Compared to other ozone catalysts reported in the literature, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance and stability in practical conditions. 3.7 Mechanism of the reaction between 10CeOx/MnOx-300 and ozone Fig. 9 shows the XPS spectra of fresh 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst and after 6 h reaction. Table 5 summarized the surface chemical compositions molar ratios and chemical states of 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst before and after the reaction. From Fig. 9 and Table 5, the increase of adsorbed oxygen after 6 h reaction indicated the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst produced surface adsorbed oxygen species (O2-, O2 2-) in the zone decomposition process, which were intermediates in the decomposition of ozone. It could be clearly observed that the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ decreased from 4.08 to 1.69, and the ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ decreased from 0.37 to 0.25, the average valence state of Mn increased from 2.81 to 3.55, indicating the metal ions in the catalyst will be converted from low valence state to high valence state during ozone decomposition: Mn3+ → Mn4+, Ce3+ → Ce4+. Therefore, we inferred the relationship between metal ions in the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst and ozone decomposition was as follows: 3 O 3 + 2 Mn 3 + + 2 Ce 3 + → 3 O 2 + 2 Mn 4 + + 2 Ce 4 + + O 2 − + O 2 2 − O 3 + 2 Mn 4 + + 2 Ce 4 + + O 2 − + O 2 2 − → 3 O 3 + 2 Mn 3 + + 2 Ce 3 + Mn 3 + + Ce 4 + ⇌ Mn 4 + + Ce 3 + In addition, the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst has abundant oxygen vacancies, which were also essential for the decomposition of ozone decomposition. According to the above analysis and reports in related literatures [59–62], we inferred the ozone decomposition mechanism of the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst involving oxygen vacancy under humid conditions was exhibited in Fig. 10. Firstly, O3 molecules reacts with oxygen vacancies on the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst surface to form O2- and O2 molecules; then O2- farther reacts with O3 molecules to generate O2 2- and O2 molecules; finally, O2 2- is dissolved to generate O2 molecules and left from oxygen vacancies. Thereinto, most of the H2O molecules can pass through the catalyst by the pore structure, and other H2O molecules will adsorb on catalyst surface and occupy part of oxygen vacancies, these water molecules will be desorbed from the oxygen vacancies after heat treatment. 4 Conclusions The 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts modified with the Mn-BTC by doping cerium and calcining methods have been prepared to decompose ozone. The as-prepared 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst was suitable for ozone removal under the wider RH range from less than 5–65 % and low gas flow rate conditions, which exhibited 100% ozone conversion for 6 h under the conditions of 40 ppm O3, RH = 65 % and the total gas flow of 1000 ml/min at room temperature. Based on the characterizations of morphology and phase structures, appropriate calcination temperature induced the formation of the Mn2O3 phase, avoided crystal agglomeration, enlarged the specific surface area of catalysts and exposed more active sites to absorb ozone. In addition, appropriate calcination temperature promoted the formation of Mn3+, Ce3+, surface adsorbed oxygen species and oxygen vacancies, enhanced reducibility of catalysts proved by H2-TPR and XPS. All these properties can enhance the activity of the catalyst for ozone decomposition. This research offers a significant directive to control the catalytic O3 decomposition by modifying MOFs. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous 10CeOx/MnOx-Y catalysts were successfully prepared by doping Ce and calcining Mn-BTC (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) for ozone catalytic decomposition. The 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity under the relative humidity (RH) range from less than 5–65 %, giving 100 % conversion of 40 ppm O3 after 6 h. Series of physicochemical characterizations including XRD, TG, SEM, HR-TEM, ICP-OES, BET, XPS and H2-TPR were introduced the relationship of calcination temperature, catalysts structure and ozone catalytic performance. The results demonstrated that the 10CeOx/MnOx-300 catalyst had the highest Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olatt ratios and the largest specific surface compared with those of other samples, which are crucial to decompose ozone. In addition, better dispersion of crystals, larger pore volume, more oxygen vacancies, and better low-temperature reducibility are also conducive to ozone decomposition. This research establishes the basis for the application of manganese-based MOFs for ozone decomposition.
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous CeOx/MnOx catalyst derived from Mn-BTC for ozone catalytic decomposition
